preface.title: Preface
preface.para: Apache Isis is designed to allow programmers rapidly develop domain-driven applications following the Naked Objects pattern. It is made up of a core framework plus a number of alternate implementations, and supports various viewers and object stores. Apache Isis is hosted at the Apache Foundation, and is licensed under Apache Software License v2.

This guide is written for programmers who want to use the SQL Object Store to persist domain objects running within the Apache Isis framework. Specifically, it covers how to write repository implementations, how to configure the object store, and how to deploy your applications using the object store.

sect1.title: Background
sect1.para: The SQL objectstore provides a fully-automatic object store that uses a jdbc SQL-compatible database server.

All domain objects (entities) are introspected during initialisation, and have a 1-to-1 mapping onto a database table. All properties (values) are mapped onto one or more columns with each database table.
Domain object classes are introspected and all properties recursively introspected to value types. Thus, if a property stores a reference to a class, that class's properties are introspected, etc.

sect2.title: Properties
sect2.para: The SQL objectstore is setup via the isis.properties file. The required variables are given below:
The driver property must contain the name of the jdbc driver class that provides access to your SQL server. Known examples are given below in .

sect2.title: Table Creation
sect2.para: Missing database tables are automatically created when the SQL objectstore is initialised.

Please note that changes to domain classes such as renaming fields (properties) or the classes themselves, are not automatically detected. If you rename a property after a table has been created, you should use the appropriate database administration tool to rename the column in the containing table.
If you rename a domain class (entity), you must also rename the appropriate table.

sect1.title: Mappers
sect1.para: The mappers take care of mapping a value type onto a SQL data type. Default mappers are provided by JdbcFieldMappingFactoryInstaller.

sect2.title: Modifiable values
sect2.para: The following SQL datatypes can be overridden, if specified in the properties file (the default value is given in parenthesis), [the mapped value classes are given in square brackets]: isis.persistor.sql.datatypes.timestamp (DATETIME) [TimeStamp, java.sql.Timestamp]
The final value, primarykey, is a special value.

In general, be very careful about changing the SQL data type, as the default value mappers are written assuming the default values. Data parsing uses prepared statements and reads/writes values as objects.
The datatype longstring is used to store classnames, required for polymorphism.

sect2.title: Floating Point Value Limits
sect2.para: Caution: Testing on certain database servers (MySQL and PostgreSQL) has shown that floats and doubles (stored as FLOAT or DOUBLE PRECISION respectively) are not stored to the same resolution as supported by Java. The tested range of float is 1E-37 to 1E38, and the tested range of double is 1E-307 to 1E308.

sect2.title: Fixed values
sect2.para: The following classes are not modifiable:
[char] is set to CHAR(1)
[Money] value is FLOAT, currency is VARCHAR(3)
[Percentage] is FLOAT

sect1.title: Naming Conventions
sect1.para: While case is determined by the capabilities of the database driver, all SQL names will be written in UPPER CASE, below.

sect2.title: Tables
sect2.para: By default, all Isis tables are preceded with "ISIS_". This behaviour can be altered by specifying a replacement table prefix. See .

sect3.title: Domain Tables
sect3.para: Only the "class" part of the package name is used. Thus a domain class called "some.package.Client", will be mapped onto a table "ISIS_CLIENT" (assuming that the default table prefix has not been changed).

sect3.title: Internal column: pk_id
sect3.para: The default ID column name is "PK_ID", but this can be over-ridden by specifying the new name in the properties file:

para.property: Used internally by Isis to record services, in the table "ISIS_ADMIN_SERVICES".

sect3.title: Properties
sect3.para: Most properties are named as per the class property. This means you must take care not to use SQL reserved labels are property names. The exceptions are collections and multi-field values (e.g. Money).

sect3.title: Collections
sect3.para: Collections are mapped onto the child class:

If a parent class (some.package.Parent) has a collection of (some.other.package.Child) named "children", the child table (ISIS_CHILD) gets a column labeled "FK_PARENT_CHILDREN" of type primarykey. The child property is assigned the ID of the parent class.
This means that a given child can only appear in one parent's collection of the same name.

sect3.title: Multi-field values
sect3.para: Some value types need more than 1 field to store their values, e.g. Money - some.package.class#price.
In this case, the SQL objectstore creates 2 fields, price1 and price2.

sect1.title: Password values
sect1.para: The JdbcPasswordValueMapper value mapper has the ability to (weakly) encode the password value strings stored in the database tables.
By adding the following property values:
You can enable a weak password encoding/decoding scheme that will obscure password values from casual browsers of your database tables.
The length of all stored passwords is the same, and determined by the isis.persistor.sql.default.password.length property. This length must not exceed the SQL storage, as defined in .
The passwords are convolved with the value of the string given by the isis.persistor.sql.default.password.seed property, and the resulting string is stored in the database table.
If isis.persistor.sql.default.password.seed is undefined (null), the passwords are stored as plain text.

chapter.title: Polymorphism
chapter.para: The SQL Objectstore supports polymorphic classes. Both properties and collections are supported.

sect1.title: Properties
sect1.para: Polymorphic properties are handled with JdbcPolymorphicObjectReferenceMapping.
Two columns are created in the class table: The actual instance class type, and the instance ID.

sect1.title: Collections
sect1.para: There are two implementations currently selectable by editting AbstractAutoMapper.
The default implementation is PolymorphicForeignKeyInChildCollectionBaseMapper.

sect2.title: PolymorphicForeignKeyInChildCollectionBaseMapper
sect2.para: Creates two columns in the child class table, to contain the child class type and child class ID.
Used to map 1-to-many collections by creating, in the collection child table (which may be an interface or abstract class), 2 columns per parent collection.
The first column is the class type, the second is the entity ID.
The columns are named by combining the final part of the parent class name and the collection variable name.
Collection loading is a case of iterating through all collection entries and adding the named class instance of the stored ID.

sect2.title: PolymorphicForeignKeyInChildCollectionMapper
sect2.para: Used to map 1-to-many collections by creating, in the child table, 1 column per parent collection.
The column is named by combining the final part of the parent class name and the collection variable name.

Collection loading is a case of iterating through all subclasses of the collection type and adding class instances of the stored ID. This could be problematic if different subclasses have the same ID.

For example:

sect2.para: You could also peruse some of the Hibernate ORM docs for examples of mappings there; that might prompt you to consider some additional scenarios.

Obviously, any additional entries required in isis.properties to enable the SQL object store. In addition, as background it'd be worth explaining about the different subcomponents used by the object store: the OidGenerator, PersistAlgorithm, TransactionManager Also, I know that the JPA object store has to configure a different ClassSubstitutor/ObjectFactory, because it leaves the ORM to perform cglib proxying.
